title: Three Ways to Prime Students for Learning
tldr: Outlines three priming techniques: pre-exposure, activating prior knowledge and retrieval practice.
Pre-exposure involves previewing content to build a mental scaffold before class.
Activating prior knowledge and performing brain dumps reduce cognitive load and enhance retention.
try_tomorrow: Spend 3–5 minutes skimming headings and bold terms before your next class.
Write down what you already know and at least three questions you expect to answer.
Do a 2-minute brain dump immediately after class to summarise what stuck.

title: Spacing Practice and Working Memory
tldr: Shows that spaced practice does not require more time than cramming but yields much better retention【554216430977859†L67-L95】.
Experiment with primary school students found that spacing reduces working memory depletion and improves performance【554216430977859†L173-L178】.
Recommends scheduling brief retrieval sessions across days instead of massed study.
try_tomorrow: Replace one long study block with two shorter sessions separated by a day.
Use a calendar to plan 8-minute recall sessions 1 day and 3 days after learning.
Resist the urge to re-read notes; test yourself instead.

title: Retrieval Practice Produces More Learning Than Elaborative Studying with Concept Mapping
tldr: Reports experiments showing students who practiced retrieval outperformed those who created concept maps on tests of meaningful learning【560033971467502†L295-L309】.
Retrieval practice strengthens memory and facilitates transfer to new contexts【560033971467502†L295-L309】.
Highlights that elaborative studying alone is insufficient without active recall.
try_tomorrow: End every study session by recalling key ideas without looking at notes.
Create three questions and answer them from memory to consolidate understanding.
Mix retrieval with concept mapping by adding self-quiz prompts to your maps.

title: Mix It Up: The Benefits of Interleaved Practice
tldr: Explains how interleaving problems and topics helps learners differentiate between problem types and promotes transfer【999445851119787†L23-L38】.
Suggests incorporating cumulative quizzes and integrated projects to encourage interleaved practice【999445851119787†L23-L38】.
Highlights that mixing topics yields higher performance than blocked practice.
try_tomorrow: When doing homework, alternate between two topics instead of completing one fully before moving on.
Create a mini-quiz with problems from different subjects to practice interleaving.
Review and compare solutions across topics to notice similarities and differences.

title: How Analogies Strengthen Memory and Understanding
tldr: Describes research showing analogies help students connect new information to prior knowledge and improve comprehension【699215777082179†L85-L113】.
Suggests teachers deliberately select analogies that are familiar to learners to enhance memory.
Encourages students to generate their own analogies to make abstract concepts intuitive.
try_tomorrow: When learning a difficult concept, think of a real-life analogy that shares the same structure.
Add a short analogy note beside each new idea in your notes to anchor it to something familiar.
Explain a new topic to a friend using an analogy to check if it sticks.

title: Mindsets and Learning: Why Beliefs About Intelligence Matter
source: Psychological Science in the Public Interest
tldr: Summarises research on fixed versus growth mindsets and how beliefs shape learning outcomes.
Students with a growth mindset seek challenges and persist despite setbacks, leading to higher achievement.
Emphasises that intelligence is malleable and can be increased through effort and strategy.
try_tomorrow: Set a small, challenging goal and treat mistakes as opportunities to learn, not evidence of lack of ability.
Replace self-talk like ‘I can’t do this’ with ‘I can’t do this yet’ to encourage growth.
Reflect on past successes that resulted from persistence to reinforce a growth mindset.
